awd_titl_txt: Louis Stokes B2B Alliance: Central Florida STEM Alliance Paths to Engagement : Central Florida STEM Alliance Paths to Engagement
awd_abstract_narration:
The Louis Stokes Alliances for Minority Participation (LSAMP) program assists universities and colleges in diversifying the science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) workforce through their efforts at significantly increasing the numbers of students from historically underrepresented minority populations to successfully complete high-quality degree programs in STEM.  Over the next three years, the Central Florida STEM Alliance (CFSA), an alliance of four community colleges, will partner with three baccalaureate degree-granting institutions (Florida Agricultural and Mechanical University, Florida Institute of Technology, and Florida Polytechnic University) from the State University System of Florida to support the retention, transfer, and successful graduation of Alliance students in STEM fields.  The alliance institutions include Valencia Community College (Lead institution), College of Central Florida, Pasco-Hernando State College, and Polk State College.

Building on the Alliance’s past successes, it will continue to work with students who are historically underrepresented in STEM fields while studying innovative and evidence-based strategies to maximize STEM opportunities for community college students.  The project will achieve a 30% net increase in the number of students who successfully transfer into STEM baccalaureate degree programs over the three-year project period.  The CFSA will analyze innovative strategies aligned with the intersection of sense of belonging, STEM identity, STEM self-efficacy, and the impact these factors have on persistence in STEM pathways among minoritized students. This project will more deeply examine the conditions under which targeted students begin to identify as emerging STEM professionals and as belonging to a STEM community, building on the LSAMP program theory and Tinto Model (1987) by examining the social, emotional, educational, financial, and cultural conditions that accelerate student progress in the community college context.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Div. of Equity for Excellence in STEM

por.por_cntn:
The Central Florida STEM Alliance (CFSA)  connected four community college partners: College of Central Florida, Pasco-Hernando State College, Polk State College, and Valencia College. The alliance established two goals for its Paths to Engagement project: 1) Provide meaningful engagement for underrepresented minority STEM students so they are better prepared to succeed in STEM baccalaureate programs and 2) Increase the number of underrepresented minority students who successfully transfer into STEM baccalaureate programs at partner institutions.

Intellectual Merit:

CFSA colleges implemented activities based on high impact practices and proven approaches to support degree and career attainment by  URM students in STEM. Alliance colleges contributed to advancing knowledge and understanding in academia using practices and strategies that:

  • Delivered clear and targeted STEM advising, associated student support services, and diverse opportunities for deep engagement in STEM.
  • Encouraged individual students’ sense of belonging, self-efficacy, and identity development as learners, community contributors, and emerging STEM professionals.
  • Increased opportunities for students to establish/expand personal and professional networks while building career skills and exploring opportunities to use STEM knowledge and skills for meaningful impact through internships, undergraduate research, and projects related to community impact.
  • Expanded institutional and regional capacity to support the STEM degree enrollment, persistence, and attainment of underrepresented minority students through comprehensive programming and collaborations.

 

Broader Impacts:

CFSA colleges successfully increased the number of URM students transferring into STEM baccalaureate degree programs at six partner universities. Increasing the participation of URM students in STEM at academic institutions and beyond amplifies diversity in the U.S. STEM educational ecosystem and subsequent professional fields. LSAMP students engaged in programming to understand more clearly how obtaining a degree in STEM could positively contribute to society and their own communities. Students who participated in the Summer STEM Institute  - a bridge program for incoming first-time-in-college students at CFSA institutions - worked on group projects to develop STEM-based solutions to advance attainment of the United Nations Sustainable Development Goals, with an emphasis on local solutions for environmental and societal challenges in Central Florida. CFSA students also volunteered in their communities, engaged in STEM outreach, and made positive societal contributions through research and community-focused projects.

 

 Key Outcomes:

  • Transfers: The CFSA Paths to Engagement project established a goal to realize a 30% increase over the baseline for associate-degree (AA), URM STEM student transfers. Comparing this baseline (determined as the median transfer count under the previous CFSA grant (2017-2021), CFSA achieved a 40.8% increase in the number of URM students transferring with AA degrees from CFSA institutions and enrolling in STEM degree programs at CFSA partner universities (Florida Agricultural & Mechanical University, Florida Institute of Technology, Florida Polytechnic University, University of Central Florida, University of Florida, and University of South Florida).
  • Engagement in STEM: CFSA developed and implemented co-curricular and academic enrichment programs to promote students’ consistent, deeper interest and engagement in STEM. Students and faculty/staff engaged in more than 450 project activities. Students participated in project activities in various ways – engaging in undergraduate research and industry internships, attending regional and national STEM conferences and, for some, making research presentations, and serving as peer coaches and leaders to support their STEM peers. 
  • Participation in undergraduate research:  CFSA Paths to Engagement provided opportunities for URM students to complete mentored STEM research at a CFSA institution while earning an AA degree. The students’ research commitment included creating a poster and presenting their research project during an institution-wide showcase. Forty-three CFSA students conducted research as research scholars (31) and community interns (12) during this project.

 

CFSA Paths to Engagement also focused on increasing URM student participation in research experiences for undergraduates (REUs). Fourteen CFSA students participated in summer REUs during this grant, conducting research in locations such as American College of Medicine, Boston University, Indiana University, National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration, Ohio State University, Penn State University, University of Maryland, and University of South Florida. 

  • Peer mentorship and leadership development: Through their participation as peer coaches, ten students improved their mentorship and leadership abilities by supporting peers in the completion of research projects, serving as tutors, and leading workshops to share guidance, strategies, and skills with fellow students.
  • Industry partnership: Collaborative efforts with an industry partner afforded 39 students opportunity to participate in a ten-week internship. During the program students worked with management personnel on real-world issues the company faced. The organizing team reported expanded interest among company managers in hosting summer interns in their divisions. During the grant period, the summer internship program grew from 15 interns in summer of 2022 to 21 interns in summer 2024. While students from other institutions could apply to and be selected for the program, each year at least 67% of the participants were CFSA students. Students who completed the program received a $4,000 scholarship to support their continued studies toward a baccalaureate degree in a STEM major.

Last Modified: 10/28/2024
Modified by: Eda Davis-Lowe
